{{Infobox NFL season | logo = | team = Miami Dolphins | year = 2007 | record = 1â15 | division_place = 4th [[AFC East]] | coach = [[Cam Cameron]] | general manager = [[Randy Mueller]] | stadium = [[Dolphin Stadium]] | playoffs = ''did not qualify'' | pro bowlers = 1 | uniform = Image:AFCE-Uniform-MIA.PNG }} The '''[[2007 NFL season|2007]] [[Miami Dolphins]] season''' was the 38th season for the team in the [[National Football League]] and 42nd season overall.<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins History | work = NFL-History.com | url = http://www.nfl-history.com/dolphins.php | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> The team nearly went winless for the season, but on December 16, the third to last game of the regular season, they beat the [[Baltimore Ravens]], giving them a final record of 1â15 . The [[Detroit Lions]] became the [[2008 Detroit Lions season|first team to go 0â16]] the [[2008 NFL season|following season.]] Their only win of the season gave them the first pick in the 2008 NFL draft. They also failed to improve upon a 6â10 season in 2006.<ref>{{cite web | title = Miami Dolphins 2006 Schedule | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule/MIA/2006 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070522172426/http://www.nfl.com/teams/schedule/MIA/2006 |archivedate = May 22, 2007}}</ref> Under former head coach [[Nick Saban]] in a year that began with high hopes,<ref>{{cite news | title = Saban, Dolphins Set Sights on Overtaking Pats | work = WashingtonPost.com | url = http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/blog/2006/05/26/BL2006052600920.html | accessdate = 24 June 2007 | first=Mark | last=Maske | date=2006-05-26}}</ref> Saban resigned from the Dolphins to become the head coach at the [[University of Alabama]], after repeatedly saying he would stay with the Dolphins.<ref name="SabanLeaves">{{cite web | title = After repeated denials, Saban takes Bama job | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/ncf/news/story?id=2718488 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref> The Dolphins entered 2007 in the process of rebuilding under new head coach Cam Cameron, the former [[offensive coordinator]] for the [[San Diego Chargers]]. The coaching staff underwent significant changes, with approximately twelve coaches newly hired or re-assigned. Cameron also made various changes to the team's roster, with a more than a dozen players being added or re-signed and just as many being released, traded or allowed to sign elsewhere. Six of the team's losses in 2007 were by margins of three points or less. {{TOClimit|limit=3}}
==Notable offseason events== ===Resignation of Nick Saban=== During the 2006 season, rumors persisted of then-Dolphins head coach Nick Saban leaving for the [[University of Alabama]] at season's end. Saban denied these rumors throughout the season, to the point where on December 21 he told the South Florida media "I'm not going to be the Alabama coach."<ref name="SabanLeaves"/> Whether or not he meant it at the time is unknown, but Saban's stance softened after the season, and on January 3, 2007 Saban resigned from the Dolphins to become the new head coach of the [[Alabama Crimson Tide]].<ref name="SabanLeaves"/>
===Historic game in London=== On February 2, 2007, NFL commissioner [[Roger Goodell]] announced that the Dolphins and [[New York Giants]] would play a game at [[London]], [[England]]'s [[Wembley Stadium]]. The game â- the second regular season NFL game to take place outside of the [[United States]] and first to take place outside of North America -â counted as a home game for the Dolphins. It took place Sunday, October 28 (Week 8) with kick off at 1:00 PM ET (6:00 PM local London time). It was broadcast on [[NFL on Fox|Fox]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Dolphins Will Host Giants In London On October 28 | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5028&lid=5028 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref> The Dolphins lost the game to the Giants by a score of 13â10.
In the 72 hours following the announcement, over half a million ticket requests were received.<ref>{{cite web | title = Half A Million Ticket Requests In 72-Hour Span | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5036&lid=5036 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref> On May 17, 40,000 tickets were made available to people randomly selected from the initial requests. The tickets sold in 90 minutes.<ref>{{cite web | title = 40,000 Tickets For London Game Sell In 90 Minutes | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5181&lid=5181 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref>
===Failed trade of Dan Wilkinson=== On March 2, the [[Denver Broncos]] acquired [[defensive tackle]] [[Dan Wilkinson]] from the Dolphins in exchange for a sixth-round draft choice in the [[2007 NFL Draft]].<ref>{{cite web | title = Broncos give up draft pick to get Wilkinson from Fins | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2786760 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> A condition of the trade was that Wilkinson report to the Broncos for a physical by Friday, March 16.<ref>{{cite web | title = Wilkinson trade could be in jeopardy | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2799298 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> He did not report for the physical, and although neither team was able to reach Wilkinson by phone the deadline for him to report was extended in hopes of eventually closing the deal.<ref>{{cite web | title = Dolphins, Broncos extend deadline on 'Big Daddy' | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2800652 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref>
On March 29, the deal between the Broncos and Dolphins was finally voided.<ref name="TradeVoided">{{cite web | title = Wilkinson trade voided, Dolphins retain rights | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2820565 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> The sixth-round pick reverted back to the Broncos, and Wilkinson's rights were once again held by the Dolphins.<ref name="TradeVoided"/> After failing to attend offseason workouts with the Dolphins in the months that followed, the Dolphins finally terminated Wilkinson's contract on June 18.<ref name="WilkinsonRelease">{{cite web | title = After failing to trade him, Dolphins cut Wilkinson | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2908447 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref>
===Legal troubles=== ====Joey Porter-Levi Jones altercation==== After five seasons as [[AFC North]] rivals, former [[Pittsburgh Steelers]] linebacker [[Joey Porter]] and [[Cincinnati Bengals]] [[offensive tackle]] [[Levi Jones]] were involved in an altercation in a [[Las Vegas, Nevada|Las Vegas]] casino on March 18.
====Arrest and release of Fred Evans==== In the early morning of 2007-06-23, 23-year-old Dolphins defensive tackle [[Fred Evans (American football)|Fred Evans]] was arrested in [[Miami Beach]].<ref name="EvansArrest">{{cite web | title = Dolphins' DT Evans arrested, charged with battery | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-0623dolphins,0,2037788.story?coll=sfla-dolphins-front | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> According to the police report, Evans was in a dispute with a taxi driver, and refused to leave the cab at the request of the officers called to the scene. Evans reportedly engaged in a physical struggle with the officers when they tried to handcuff him, with one officer being bitten on his left wrist.<ref name="EvansArrest"/> The officers then used tasers to subdue Evans. He was charged with battery on a police officer, disorderly conduct, resisting arrest and trespassing.<ref name="EvansArrest"/> Complicating matters could be the fact that Evans is already on probation in [[Colorado County, Texas]] for possession of [[marijuana]].<ref name="EvansProbation">{{cite web | title = Arrested Dolphins DL Evans already on probation in Texas | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-0626dolphsevans,0,2713899.story?coll=sfla-dolphins-front | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref>
In a team-released statement, Dolphins head coach Cam Cameron said: "We are aware that Fred Evans was arrested this morning. We will not condone this type of behavior. I assure everyone it will be dealt with seriously".<ref>{{cite web | title = Statement From Miami Dolphins Head Coach Cam Cameron On Fred Evans | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5227&lid=5227 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> Cameron made good on his word a few days later, as Evans was waived by the team on June 28.<ref name = "SunSentinel-062807">{{cite web | title = Dolphins waive Fred Evans | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-dolevans062807,0,4115291.story?coll=sfla-dolphins-front | accessdate = 28 June 2007 }}</ref>
====Arrest and release of Kelly Campbell==== Re-signed by the Dolphins in March after spending 2006 training camp with the team, wide receiver [[Kelly Campbell]] had his contract terminated on July 6.<ref name="CampbellRelease">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Kelly Campbell | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5236 | accessdate = 24 July 2007 }}</ref> It was not until July 24, however, that it was revealed that Campbell's release stemmed from an arrest on drug charges in [[Atlanta, Georgia]] on July 3.<ref name="CampbellArrest">{{cite web | title = Campbell drug charges put Dolphins atop NFL in arrests | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-flspdolarrest24nbjul24,0,2510309.story | accessdate = 24 July 2007 }}</ref> Campbell was charged with felony possession of [[marijuana]] and [[Methylenedioxymethamphetamine|Ecstasy]] and a misdemeanor charge of providing false information to police officers.<ref name="CampbellArrest"/> It was Campbell's second arrest in [[Fulton County, Georgia|Fulton County]].<ref name="CampbellArrest"/> In 2005, Campbell was arrested and charged with marijuana possession and theft by receiving stolen property involving a handgun.<ref name="CampbellArrest"/> He reached a plea deal to avoid a trial.<ref name="CampbellArrest"/>
====Arrest of Chris Chambers==== On the morning of Saturday, July 14, [[Pro Bowl]] wide receiver [[Chris Chambers]] was arrested in [[Charlotte, North Carolina]] and charged with [[Driving under the influence|driving while impaired]] and speeding.<ref name="ChambersArrest">{{cite web | title = Dolphins wide receiver Chambers charged in N.C. | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2936638 | accessdate = 14 July 2007 }}</ref> He was arrested around 2:30 a.m. and later released on $1,750 bond.<ref name="ChambersArrest"/> According to Charlotte-Mecklenburg police Capt. Lisa Goelz, Chambers faced charges of driving while impaired, speeding and reckless driving.<ref name="ChambersArrest"/> On August 15, it was reported that a lawyer for Chambers said he would plead not guilty to driving while impaired.<ref name="ChambersPlea1">{{cite web | title = Chambers to plead not guilty to D.W.I. | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/news/story?id=09000d5d80182e5c&template=without-video&confirm=true | accessdate = 15 August 2007 }}</ref> Chambers was charged despite his [[blood-alcohol content]] being below the legal limit, although [[North Carolina]] law says he can still be convicted.<ref name="ChambersPlea1"/>
On September 25, it was reported that Chambers would enter a plea deal in which he would plead guilty to speeding.<ref name="ChambersPlea2">{{cite web | title = Chambers won't face DWI, reckless driving charges after plea | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=3035733 | accessdate = 25 September 2007 }}</ref> Under the terms of the plea deal, the chargers of driving while impaired and reckless driving were dismissed.<ref name="ChambersPlea2"/> He did not have to appear in court.<ref name="ChambersPlea2"/>
==Offseason personnel moves== ===Front office=== On June 26, general manager [[Randy Mueller]] signed a contract extension that is expected to keep him with the team through at least 2010.<ref name="MuellerExtension">{{cite web | title = Dolphins extend GM Randy Mueller's contract | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.sun-sentinel.com/sports/football/pro/dolphins/sfl-dolgm062807,0,6074423.story?coll=sfla-dolphins-front | accessdate = 26 June 2007 }}</ref> Mueller will also receive a salary adjustment, however financial details were unavailable.<ref name="MuellerExtension"/> After Nick Saban left following the 2006 season, Mueller's role was altered to give him control of personnel.<ref name="MuellerExtension"/>
===Coaches=== After the departure of Nick Saban, Dolphins owner [[H. Wayne Huizenga]] went on a nationwide search for his next head coach.<ref name="CameronHired">{{cite web | title = Dolphins, Cameron strike four-year deal | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2736313 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref> More than a dozen candidates were interviewed,<ref name="CameronHired"/> and on January 19 Cam Cameron agreed to become the seventh head coach in franchise history.<ref name="CameronHired"/> Cameron had previously served as offensive coordinator for the [[San Diego Chargers]] from 2002 to 2006.<ref name="CameronHired"/> He received a four-year contract worth $10 million.<ref>{{cite web | title = It's official: Tomlin is Steelers' new coach | work = FoxSports.com | url = http://msn.foxsports.com/nfl/story/6391772 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref>
Upon Cameron's arrival, multiple changes were made to the coaching staff. [[Running back]]s coach [[Bobby Williams]], [[wide receiver]]s coach [[Charlie Baggett]], [[defensive line]] coach [[Dan Quinn (football coach)|Dan Quinn]] and strength and conditioning coach [[Bert Hill]] were fired.<ref>{{cite web | title = Dolphins Release Williams From Coaching Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5114&lid=5114 | accessdate = 15 June 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Quinn Takes Jets Job | work = NYPost.com | url = http://www.nypost.com/seven/02072007/sports/jets/quinn_takes_jets_job_jets_mark_cannizzaro.htm | accessdate = 15 June 2007 | first=Mark | last=Cannizzaro | date=2007-02-07}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | title = Cameron Cleans House Sources: Hill, Baggett Among Those Fired | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/sun_sentinel/access/1199004761.html?dids=1199004761:1199004761&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Jan+22%2C+2007&author=Harvey+Fialkov+and&pub=South+Florida+Sun+-+Sentinel&edition=&startpage=C.2&desc=CAMERON+CLEANS+HOUSE+SOURCES%3A+HILL%2C+BAGGETT+AMONG+THOSE+FIRED | accessdate = 15 June 2007 | date=2007-01-22 | first=Harvey | last=Fialkov}}</ref> The team extended the contracts of [[special teams]] coordinator [[Keith Armstrong]] and outside [[linebacker]]s coach [[Travis Jones]] (later reassigned as [[defensive end]]s coach).<ref name="ArmstrongMaxieRobiskie">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Robiskie, Maxie To Coaching Staff; Capers, Armstrong Sign Contract Extensions | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5019&lid=5019 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title = Travis Jones, AC, Miami Dolphins | work = KFFL.com | url = http://www.kffl.com/player/11651/nfl/news | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> The Dolphins also signed a three-year, $8.1 million contract with defensive coordinator [[Dom Capers]] to retain his services.<ref>{{cite web | title = Dolphins to pay Capers; new head coach next? | work = ESPN.com | url = http://sports.espn.go.com/nfl/news/story?id=2730315 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> Outside additions to the staff were: *[[Mike Dumas]] (Defensive Secondary Coaches Assistant)<ref name="MularkeyReassigned">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Sign Cory Schlesinger As A UFA; 2007 Coaching Staff Completed | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5080&lid=5080 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Steve Hoffman (football coach)|Steve Hoffman]] (Assistant Special Teams)<ref name="Hoffman">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Hoffman To Coaching Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5043&lid=5043 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Bobby Jackson (football coach)|Bobby Jackson]] (Running Backs)<ref name="BobbyJackson">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Name Bobby Jackson Running Backs Coach | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5118&lid=5118 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Marvin Marshall]] (Offensive Quality Control)<ref name="ChatmanMarshall">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Marshall To Coaching Staff, Sign Chatman | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5052&lid=5052 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Brett Maxie]] (Secondary â Safeties)<ref name="ArmstrongMaxieRobiskie"/> *[[Brad Ohrt]] (Assistant Strength and Conditioning)<ref name="SheaOhrtFlinn">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Shea, Ohrt To Coaching Staff; Sign Punter | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5048&lid=5048 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Diron Reynolds]] (Defensive Line â Tackles)<ref name="ReynoldsSchiotz">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Add Reynolds, Schiotz To Coaching Staff | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5041&lid=5041 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> *[[Terry Robiskie]] (Wide Receivers)<ref name="ArmstrongMaxieRobiskie"/> *[[Matthew Schiotz]] (Strength and Conditioning)<ref name="ReynoldsSchiotz"/> *[[Terry Shea]] (Quarterbacks)<ref name="SheaOhrtFlinn"/> *[[Chad Walker]] (Defensive Quality Control)<ref name="MularkeyReassigned"/>
Finally, previous offensive coordinator [[Mike Mularkey]] was retained, but was reassigned to the role of [[tight end]]s coach.<ref name="MularkeyReassigned"/> Cameron has stated he will call the offensive plays himself in 2007.<ref name="CameronPlaycalling">{{cite web | title = Coaches Spotlight â Cam Cameron, Miami Dolphins | work = NFLHS.com | url = http://www.nflhs.com/news/coachesspotlight/camcameron_04182007_jjc.asp | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref>

====NFL Europa==== The following Dolphins players<ref>{{cite web | title = NFL Assignments to NFL Europa League | work = NFLEurope.com | url = http://nfleurope.com/news/story/10017103 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070613204351/http://www.nfleurope.com/news/story/10017103 |archivedate = June 13, 2007}}</ref> were allocated to and participated in [[NFL Europa]] in the spring: *DT [[Steve Fifita]], [[Frankfurt Galaxy]] *CB [[Shirdonya Mitchell]], Frankfurt Galaxy *WR [[P.K. Sam]], [[Rhein Fire]] *DT [[Kevin Vickerson]], [[Cologne Centurions]]
For their performances, Mitchell and Vickerson were selected to the 2007 All-NFL Europa team after the season.<ref>{{cite web | title = Vickerson, Mitchell Named First-Team All-NFL Europa | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5225&lid=5225 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> Meanwhile, Sam led Rhein in receiving with 32 receptions, 529 yards and three touchdowns.<ref>{{cite web | title = Two Dolphins named All-NFL Europa | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/sports_football_dolphins/2007/06/two-dolphins-na.html | accessdate = 25 June 2007 }}</ref>
Upon the conclusion of the 2007 NFL Europa season, the Dolphins were assigned 24-year-old wide receiver [[Marvin Allen]] as their international practice squad player.<ref name="MarvinAllen"/> Allen joined the team for training camp, and will not count toward the team's roster or eight-player practice squad.<ref name="MarvinAllen"/> He also could not be signed by any NFL team during the 2007 season.<ref name="MarvinAllen"/>

Pick |- ! 1 !! 9 | [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] || [[Wide receiver]] || [[Ohio State University|Ohio State]] || 5 ft 11 in || 178 lbs |- ! rowspan="2" | 2 !! 40 | [[John Beck (American football player)|John Beck]] || [[Quarterback]] || [[Brigham Young University|BYU]] ||6 ft 2 in || 215 lb |- ! 60 | [[Samson Satele]] || [[Center (American football)|Center]]/[[Offensive guard|Guard]] || [[University of Hawaii|Hawaii]] || 6 ft 2 in || 300 lb |- ! 3 !! 71 | [[Lorenzo Booker]] || [[Running back]] || [[Florida State University|Florida State]] || 5 ft 10 in || 191 lb |- ! 4 !! 108 | [[Paul Soliai]] || [[Defensive tackle]] || [[University of Utah|Utah]] || 6 ft 4 in || 344 lb |- ! rowspan="2" | 6 !! 181 | [[Reagan Mauia]] || [[Fullback (American football)|Fullback]] || Hawaii || 6 ft 0 in || 270 lb |- ! 199 | [[Drew Mormino]] || Center || [[Central Michigan University|Central Michigan]] || 6 ft 3 in || 299 lb |- ! rowspan="3" | 7 !! 219 | [[Kelvin Smith]] || [[Linebacker]] || [[Syracuse University|Syracuse]] || 6 ft 2 in || 233 lb |- ! 225 | [[Brandon Fields]] || [[Punter (football position)|Punter]] || [[Michigan State University|Michigan State]] || 6 ft 6 in || 235 lb |- ! 238 | [[Abraham Wright]] || [[Linebacker]] || [[University of Colorado at Boulder|Colorado]] || 6 ft 3 in || 245 lb |}
*The Dolphins' last second-round pick (60th overall) was acquired from the New England Patriots in the Wes Welker trade. The team's final pick in the draft (238th overall) was also acquired in the deal.<ref name="HarringtonMcMichaelRelease"/> *The team's fifth-round pick became property of the Detroit Lions due to the Joey Harrington trade from the previous offseason.<ref name="HarringtonAcquired">{{cite web | title = Some fishy moves at quarterback | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/10117930 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070616031336/http://www.nfl.com/nflnetwork/story/10117930 |archivedate = June 16, 2007}}</ref> *The team's second sixth-round pick (199th overall) was acquired from the New Orleans Saints for kicker Olindo Mare.<ref name="MareTrade"/> *The team's middle seventh-round pick (225th overall) was acquired from the St. Louis Rams when they signed restricted free agent punter Donnie Jones.<ref name="DonnieJonesRams"/>
=====Draft pick signings===== The Dolphins got a handful of their draft picks signed within a month of the draft, inking four-year deals with running back Lorenzo Booker, punter Brandon Fields, fullback Reagan Mauia, linebacker Kelvin Smith and linebacker Abraham Wright between May 23â25. The Dolphins signed one draft pick in June â defensive tackle Paul Soliai, who also received a four-year deal. Offensive lineman Samson Satele signed a for four years on July 18, while quarterback John Beck and center Dew Mormino signed four-year contracts on July 23. At that time, first-round pick Ted Ginn, Jr. was the only unsigned draft pick. However, on the same day that second-round pick Beck was signed, it was reported that the Dolphins and Ginn were close to contract agreement.
====Undrafted free agents==== Between May 4â17, the Dolphins signed 16 [[undrafted free agent (football)|undrafted free agents]] following the draft.<ref name="UDFAs">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Open Mini-Camp II; Team Signs Fourteen College Free Agents | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5167&lid=5167 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref><ref name="LoftonMalone">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Sign Two College Free Agents | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5183 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> They were: *DE [[Mkristo Bruce]] ([[Washington State University|Washington State]]) *S [[Courtney Bryan]] ([[New Mexico State University|New Mexico State]]) *T [[Marion Dukes]] ([[Clemson University|Clemson]]) *G [[Tala Esera]] ([[University of Hawaii|Hawaii]]) *CB [[Tuff Harris]] ([[University of Montana|Montana]]) *WR [[Gabe Hatchett]] ([[Southern Oregon University|Southern Oregon]]) *S David Lofton ([[Stanford University|Stanford]]) *DT [[Marquay Love]] ([[University of Houston|Houston]]) *WR [[Michael Malone (wide receiver)|Michael Malone]] ([[Sam Houston State University|Sam Houston State]]) *LB [[Edmond Miles]] ([[University of Iowa|Iowa]]) *G [[Stephen Parker (football player)|Stephen Parker]] ([[University of Arkansas|Arkansas]]) *CB [[Geoff Pope (football player)|Geoff Pope]] ([[Howard University|Howard]]) *WR [[Kerry Reed]] ([[Michigan State University|Michigan State]]) *WR [[David Sutton (football player)|David Sutton]] ([[University of Texas-El Paso|Texas El-Paso]]) *S Christopher Vedder ([[San Jose State University|San Jose State]]) *T [[Julius Wilson]] ([[University of Alabama-Birmingham|Alabama-Birmingham]])
Unlike the other 15, Hatchett stuck with the team less than two weeks. On May 18, Hatchett was waived upon the signings of Lofton and Malone, as well as the re-signing of restricted free agent Yeremiah Bell.<ref name="Hatchett">{{cite web | title = Culpepper Practices On Limited Basis In Team's OCS Sesson; Dolphins Waive Hatchett | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5185 | accessdate = 24 June 2007 }}</ref> On July 23, the Dolphins signed defensive tackle [[Brian Soi]] of [[Utah State University|Utah State]].<ref name="SoiSigned">{{cite web | title = Dolphins Sign Draft Choices Beck, Mormino; Add Free Agent Soi | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5253 | accessdate = 23 July 2007 }}</ref> Soi declared for the NFL's Supplemental Draft in July but went undrafted.<ref name="SoiSupp">{{cite web | title = 2007 NFL Supplemental Draft | work = NFLDraftCountdown.com | url = http://www.nfldraftcountdown.com/features/07suppdraft.html | accessdate = 23 July 2007 }}</ref><ref name="SoiUndrafted">{{cite web | title = Oliver, Gaither selected in supplemental draft | work = NFL.com | url = http://www.nfl.com/news/story/10254491 | accessdate = 23 July 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070714213345/http://www.nfl.com/news/story/10254491 |archivedate = July 14, 2007}}</ref>
==Uniforms== *The Miami Dolphins entered the 2007 season using the same uniform combinations as they used in 2006.<ref name="CurrentUniforms">{{cite web | title = Uniform will be altered | work = MiamiHerald.com | url = http://www.sportslogos.net/team.php?t=150 | accessdate = 3 July 2007 }}</ref> *It was announced during the offseason that the Dolphins would make slight alterations to their uniforms. The navy blue outline on the numbers will be thinned in hopes of making them easier to read for viewers.<ref name="JerseyAltered">{{cite web | title = Minicamp stuff | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://www.benmaller.com/archives/2007/february/13#132567 | accessdate = 3 July 2007 |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20070928120847/http://www.benmaller.com/archives/2007/february/13#132567 |archivedate = September 28, 2007}}</ref> *As with many teams that play in warm climates, the Dolphins wear all-white at home<ref name="AllWhite">{{cite web | title = Saban shows sense of humor | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/sports_football_dolphins/2006/10/saban_shows_sen.html | accessdate = 3 July 2007 }}</ref> and the aqua jersey-white pants scheme only at home night games. *While the team still has an all-aqua alternate scheme and an alternate orange jersey, they wore neither in the two years under head coach Nick Saban. *Beginning in 2007, the Dolphins' practice jerseys now have last names on the back.<ref name="PracticeJerseys">{{cite web | title = Minicamp stuff | work = Sun-Sentinel.com | url = http://blogs.sun-sentinel.com/sports_football_dolphins/2007/05/minicamp_stuff.html | accessdate = 3 July 2007 }}</ref>

==Training camp== In 2007, Miami Dolphins training camp took place at the Dolphins Training Center in [[Davie, Florida]]. Rookies reported July 22, and veterans July 27.<ref>{{cite web | title = NFL Releases Dates, Locations For 2007 Team Training Camps | work = NFLPlayers.com | url = http://www.nflplayers.com/news/news_release.aspx?id=6927 | accessdate = 28 June 2007 }}</ref> Training camp ended for veterans and married players on August 24, when they were allowed to check out of the team hotel and return home.<ref name="CampEnds">{{cite web | title = Born To Run; Other Training Camp Notes | work = MiamiDolphins.com | url = http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5334 | accessdate = 26 August 2007 }}</ref> Training camp ended for the remaining players on Saturday, August 26.<ref name="CampEnds"/>

===Transactions=== On the eve of training camp on July 23, cornerback [[AndrÃ© Goodman]] and offensive lineman [[Joe Toledo]] were placed on the [[Physically Unable to Perform]] list due to lingering injuries. Undrafted rookie defensive tackle [[Brian Soi]] was immediately placed on the Non-Football Injury list upon being signed. The following transactions were made during training camp, which began on July 27:
*July 28: Activated defensive tackle Brian Soi from the Non-Football Injury list. *July 28: Awarded tight end [[Courtney Anderson]] off waivers from the [[Oakland Raiders]]. *July 28: Waived safety [[David Lofton]]. *July 28: Placed offensive tackle [[Marion Dukes]] on the Left Squad list. *August 26: Placed offensive tackle [[Mike Rosenthal]] on Injured Reserve.<ref>[http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/fromthegame.asp?docid=28360 NEWS: GameDay Live â MiamiDolphins.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>

===Quarterback competition=== During training camp, Cameron held a battle for the starting quarterback job between [[Trent Green]] and [[Cleo Lemon]]. Green started the team's first two preseason games and completed 45 percent of his passes for 101 yards with one interception. Lemon was the second quarterback to play in each contest and completed 76 percent of his passes for 108 yards. Nevertheless, Cameron announced that Green would be the team's starting quarterback in 2007. The announcement came on August 20 with two preseason games left to be played. Lemon, who had primarily been no higher than third string in his NFL career, is slated to be the backup to Green in 2007.

===Cutdown to 75=== With NFL rules mandating team rosters must be cut down to 75 players by August 28, the Dolphins released nine players the day before to reach the limit. Those released were: placekicker [[Matt Prater]], punter [[Ryan Flinn]], wide receiver [[David Sutton (American football)|David Sutton]], tight end [[Jason Rader]], cornerback [[Shirdonya Mitchell]], safeties [[Chris Harrell]] and [[Christopher Vedder]], running back [[Ray Perkins (running back)|Ray Perkins]] and defensive tackle [[Kevin Vickerson]].
The team made two extra roster moves on the cutdown day. Offensive guard/tackle [[Joe Toledo]] was moved to the Reserve/Physically Unable to Perform list, meaning he would be eligible to return Week 7 of the regular season. Free agent linebacker/defensive end [[Jorge Cordova]] was added to the roster. Cordova had been released by the [[Jacksonville Jaguars]], with which he had spent the previous three seasons.
===Cutdown to 53 and subsequent moves=== On September 1, the Dolphins were required to trim the roster to 53 for the regular season. With 22 roster moves needed in all, the Dolphins waived 16 players, waived/injured four and terminated the contracts of two.
The two veterans that had their contracts terminated were fullback [[Cory Schlesinger]] and wide receiver [[Az-Zahir Hakim]]. The four waived/injured players were guard [[Dan Stevenson]], wide receiver [[P. K. Sam]] and linebackers [[Jim Maxwell (American football)|Jim Maxwell]] and [[Robert McCune]]. In addition, the 16 players that were waived outright were: {| |- |valign="top"| * TE [[Courtney Anderson]] * DE [[Mkristo Bruce]] * DE [[Jorge Cordova]] * FB [[Kyle Eckel]] * G [[Tala Esera]] * TE [[Aaron Halterman]] * QB [[Gibran Hamdan]] * S [[Tuff Harris]] |valign="top"| * CB [[Derrick Johnson (cornerback)|Derrick Johnson]] * G [[Marquay Love]] * WR [[Michael Malone]] * TE [[Tim Massaquoi]] * G [[Stephen Parker (American football)|Stephen Parker]] * CB [[Geoffrey Pope (American football)|Geoff Pope]] * DT [[Brian Soi]] * OT [[Julius Wilson]] |}
The Dolphins' roster was not finalized immediately after cuts, however. Three players were claimed off waivers by the Dolphins from other teams, requiring an additional three roster moves. On September 2, wide receiver [[Kerry Reed]] and center [[Johnathan Ingram]] were waived, while rookie center/guard [[Drew Mormino]] was played in season-ending [[Injured Reserve]] with a shoulder injury. The Dolphins claimed two players off waivers from the [[San Diego Chargers]] â wide receiver [[Greg Camarillo]] and offensive tackle [[Cory Lekkerkerker]]. Meanwhile, offensive lineman [[Gene Mruczkowski]] was claimed off waivers from the [[New England Patriots]].
Five days later, defensive end [[Rob Ninkovich]] was claimed off waivers from the [[New Orleans Saints]]. To make room for him, rookie linebacker [[Kelvin Smith]] was waived.
Two Dolphins players changed their jersey numbers following the preseason. Long snapper [[John Denney]], who wore No. 97 the first two years of his career, switched to No. 92. Undrafted rookie linebacker [[Edmond Miles]] switched from No. 48 to 50 to comply with NFL rules.
===Practice squad=== On September 2 the Dolphins made five additions to their practice squad, all of which among the players cut by the team the day before. Those players were tight end [[Aaron Halterman]], safety [[Tuff Harris]], guard [[Marquay Love]] and offensive tackle [[Julius Wilson]] and wide receiver [[Marvin Allen]]. As the international practice squad player, Allen must remain on the team's practice squad all year and does not count toward the eight-man limit.
Two days later, the Dolphins signed three more players â guard [[Tala Esera]], wide receiver [[Kerry Reed]] and wide receiver [[Chandler Williams]] â to their practice squad. Esera and Reed were with the Dolphins in preseason and released earlier in the month. Chandler, meanwhile, was a seventh-round pick by the [[Minnesota Vikings]] in the [[2007 NFL Draft]] out of [[FIU Golden Panthers Football|Florida International University]]. He was waived by the team during final cuts on September 1.

===Game summaries=== ====Week 1: at Washington Redskins==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0||R2=7||R3=3||R4=3||R5=0||RT=13 |Home='''Redskins''' |H1=0||H2=3||H3=7||H4=3||H5=3||HT=16 |stadium= [[FedEx Field]], [[Landover, Maryland]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 82Â°F (Sunny) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Dan Dierdorf]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Gene Steratore]] |attendance= 90,163 }} The Dolphins began their 2007 campaign on the road against the [[Washington Redskins]]. After a scoreless first quarter, the Redskins made the first move with kicker [[Shaun Suisham]] getting a 31-yard field goal three minutes into the second quarter. Miami would take the lead before the end of the half with a one-yard touchdown pass from [[Trent Green]] to [[tight end]] [[Justin Peelle]] as time expired.
Washington took a 10â7 lead on a 19-yard [[Clinton Portis]] touchdown run with just under 12 minutes remaining in the third quarter. Dolphins kicker Jay Feely tied the game at 10 later in the quarter on a 20-yard field goal, and each team notched another field goal in the fourth quarter. With four seconds remaining and the ball on the Washington 43-yard line, Redskins quarterback [[Jason Campbell]] launched a last-second [[Hail Mary pass]] that was batted by Dolphins defensive end [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] in the end zone. Redskins wide receiver [[Antwaan Randle El]] caught the ball at the six but was tackled at the three-yard line before he could score the winning touchdown.
The Redskins won the coin toss to begin overtime and promptly mounted a 10-play, 62-yard drive that included just two passes. Suisham made his third field goal of the game, this time from 39 yards out, to win the game 16â13 and hand Miami their first loss of the season as they started out 0â1 and 0-1 against NFC Opponents.
====Week 2: vs. Dallas Cowboys==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Cowboys''' |R1=3||R2=7||R3=10||R4=17||RT=37 |Home=Dolphins |H1=3||H2=3||H3=7||H4=7||HT=20 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 4:05 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 89Â°F (Mostly Cloudy) |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kenny Albert]] ([[play-by-play]]), [[Daryl Johnston]] ([[color commentator]]), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) |referee= [[Terry McAulay]] |attendance= 71,615 }} Attempting to rebound from their overtime road loss to the Redskins in Week 1, the Dolphins hosted the [[Dallas Cowboys]] in Week 2. In the first quarter, Miami got the first points of the game when kicker [[Jay Feely]] converted a 37-yard field goal. The Cowboys would respond with a 26-yard field goal by [[Nick Folk]]. In the second quarter, Dallas took the lead on a 1-yard [[Marion Barber III]] touchdown run. Jay Feely made a 45-yard field goal attempt as the half ended with the Cowboys leading 10â6.
In the third quarter, Miami regained the lead with quarterback [[Trent Green]] completing an 18-yard TD pass to wide receiver [[Marty Booker]]. However, the Cowboys jumped back out in front with quarterback [[Tony Romo]] completing a 2-yard touchdown pass to tight end [[Tony Curtis (American football)|Tony Curtis]], which was followed by Folk kicking a 28-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Dallas extended the lead with Folk's 47-yard field goal and Romo's 34-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Terrell Owens]]. The Dolphins tried to come back as Green completed a 21-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver [[Derek Hagan]], but the Cowboys managed to put the game away with Barber's 40-yard touchdown run as Miami fell to 0â2 and 0-2 against NFC Opponents.
====Week 3: at New York Jets==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0 |R2=13 |R3=0 |R4=15 |RT=28 |Home='''Jets''' |H1=7 |H2=14 |H3=3 |H4=7 |HT=31 |stadium= [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]], [[East Rutherford, New Jersey]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 72Â°F (Clear) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Dan Dierdorf]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Bill Leavy]] |attendance= 77,197 }} Trying to snap a two-game skid, the Dolphins flew to [[Giants Stadium|The Meadowlands]] for Week 3 in an AFC East duel against the [[New York Jets]] (who were also 0â2 heading into the game). In the first quarter, the Jets flew out first with QB [[Chad Pennington]] completing a 3-yard TD pass to WR [[Laveranues Coles]] for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, Miami took the lead with RB [[Ronnie Brown]]'s 1-yard TD run. However, it was short lived as on the ensuing kickoff, RB [[Leon Washington]] returned the kick 98 yards for a touchdown. The Dolphins drew closer with kicker [[Jay Feely]]'s 31-yard and 39-yard field goal. However, New York responded with Pennington completing a 4-yard TD pass to TE [[Chris Baker (tight end)|Chris Baker]].
In the third quarter, the Jets increased their lead with kicker [[Mike Nugent]]'s 21-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, New York settled with Pennington getting a 2-yard TD run. Miami nearly had a comeback as Brown got a 2-yard TD run, a 2-point conversion run, and a 22-yard TD pass from QB [[Trent Green]]. However, the Jets managed to hold on to win the game.
With their third-straight loss, the Dolphins fell to 0â3.
====Week 4: vs. Oakland Raiders==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Raiders''' |R1=14 |R2=0 |R3=7 |R4=14 |RT=35 |Home=Dolphins |H1=0 |H2=7 |H3=10 |H4=0 |HT=17 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:32 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 82Â°F (Cloudy with Intermittent Rain) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Steve Tasker]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |attendance= 70,621 }} Still searching for their first win of the year, the Dolphins went home for a Week 4 duel with the [[Oakland Raiders]], featuring former teammate [[Daunte Culpepper]]. The game was delayed for 30 minutes due to thunderstorms in the area.
In the first quarter, Miami trailed early as Culpepper completed a 7-yard TD pass to WR [[Jerry Porter (American football)|Jerry Porter]]. He even got a 2-yard TD run. In the second quarter, the Dolphins managed to get on the board with RB [[Ronnie Brown]] getting a 9-yard TD run for the only score of the period. In the third quarter, the 'Fins managed to get closer with kicker [[Jay Feely]] getting a 29-yard field goal, yet Oakland answered with Culpepper getting a 5-yard TD run. Miami would end the period with QB [[Trent Green]] completing a 3-yard TD pass to TE [[Justin Peelle]]. In the fourth quarter however, Culpepper delivered the final blows by hooking up with Porter again on a 27-yard TD pass and getting a 3-yard TD run.
With their fourth-straight loss, the Dolphins fell to 0â4.
====Week 5: at Houston Texans==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=10||R2=6||R3=0||R4=3||RT=19 |Home='''Texans''' |H1=7||H2=3||H3=6||H4=6||HT=22 |stadium= [[Reliant Stadium]], [[Houston, Texas]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[North American Eastern Standard Time Zone|EST]]/12:00 p.m. [[North American Central Time Zone|CST]] |weather= Game Played With Dome Closed |attendance= 70,156 |referee= [[Tony Corrente]] }} Still searching for their first win of the year, the Dolphins flew to [[Reliant Stadium]] for a Week 5 showdown with the [[Houston Texans]]. In the first quarter, Miami's struggles continued with Texans RB [[Ron Dayne]] getting a 1-yard TD run. Fortunately, the 'Fins answered with kicker [[Jay Feely]] getting a 23-yard field goal. However, with less than 4 minutes to go in the period, history came back to haunt QB [[Trent Green]]. During an offensive play, WR [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] was running with the ball and Green went low to block DT [[Travis Johnson]]. Trent would end up getting hit in the head with Johnson's knee, knocking him unconscious with a concussion. Johnson would then get flagged for taunting the uncoscious Trent Green. With Green out of the game, back-up [[Cleo Lemon]] came in and helped the Dolphins take the lead with RB [[Ronnie Brown]] getting a 3-yard TD run. In the second quarter, Miami would increased its lead with Feely getting a 40-yard and a 33-yard field goal. Houston would end the half with kicker [[Kris Brown]] getting a 54-yard field goal.
In the third quarter, the Dolphins' lead was erased with Brown giving Houston a 43-yard and a 54-yard field goal. In the fourth quarter, Miami reclaimed the lead with Feely kicking a 48-yard field goal. However, the Texans would pull out the win with Brown getting not only a 20-yard field goal, but a gut-punching 57-yard field goal.
With their fifth-straight loss, not only did the Dolphins fall to 0â5, but they also suffered their first 8-straight losing streak since 1967.
====Week 6: at Cleveland Browns==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=3||R2=7||R3=14||R4=7||RT=31 |Home='''Browns''' |H1=14||H2=13||H3=0||H4=14||HT=41 |stadium= [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]], [[Cleveland, Ohio]] |time= 1:03 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 58Â°F (Sunny) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Ian Eagle]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Solomon Wilcots]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Larry Nemmers]] |attendance= 73,198 }} Still looking for their first win of the year, the Dolphins flew to [[Cleveland Browns Stadium]] for a Week 6 intraconference duel with the [[Cleveland Browns]]. With QB [[Trent Green]] still suffering from a concussion from last week, back-up QB [[Cleo Lemon]] was given the start.
In the first quarter, Miami trailed early as Browns RB [[Jason Wright]] got a 1-yard TD run. The 'Fins would respond with kicker [[Jay Feely]] getting a 43-yard field goal. However, Cleveland increased its lead with QB [[Derek Anderson (American football)|Derek Anderson]] getting a 1-yard TD run. In the second quarter, Miami's struggles continued with Browns kicker [[Phil Dawson]] getting a 40-yard field goal, along with Anderson completing a 24-yard TD pass to WR [[Braylon Edwards]]. The Dolphins answered with Lemon completing a 14-yard TD pass to TE [[David Martin (American football)|David Martin]], yet Cleveland managed to get a 20-yard field goal from Dawson as time ran out.
In the third quarter, the 'Fins started to retaliate with Lemon getting a 5-yard and a 1-yard TD run. Unfortunately, in the fourth quarter, the Browns would pull away with Anderson and Edwards hooking up with each other on a 5-yard and a 16-yard TD pass. Miami's only response would be Lemon's 4-yard TD pass to Martin.
With the loss, not only did the Dolphins fall to 0â6 for the first time since 2004, but they also suffered their 9th-straight loss (the worst losing streak in franchise history).
Along with the St. Louis Rams, it marked the first time since 2000 (Bengals & Chargers) that two teams began a season at 0â6.
====Week 7: vs New England Patriots==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Patriots''' |R1=14||R2=28||R3=0||R4=7||RT=49 |Home=Dolphins |H1=0||H2=7||H3=0||H4=21||HT=28 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 85Â°F (Sunny) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Greg Gumbel]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Dan Dierdorf]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Peter Morelli]] |attendance= 71,951 }} Still searching for their first win of the year, the Dolphins returned home for a Week 7 AFC East duel with the undefeated [[New England Patriots]]. In the first quarter, Miami's struggles continued as Patriots QB [[Tom Brady]] completed a 30-yard TD pass to WR [[DontÃ© Stallworth]] and a 2-yard TD pass to TE [[Kyle Brady]]. In the second quarter, the Dolphins got their only score of the half with QB [[Cleo Lemon]] getting a 4-yard TD run. Afterwards, New England continued its pounding with CB [[Willie Andrews]] returning a kickoff 77 yards for a touchdown, along with Brady and WR [[Randy Moss]] hooking up with each other on a 35-yard and a 50-yard TD pass. The Patriots would end the half with Brady hooking up with WR [[Wes Welker]] on a 14-yard TD pass.
After a scoreless third quarter, Miami tried to make a comeback in the fourth quarter. It began with RB [[Patrick Cobbs]] getting a 1-yard TD run, along with DE [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] returning an interception 36 yards for a touchdown. However, New England made sure that they sealed their victory with Brady hooking up with Welker again on a 16-yard TD pass. Afterwards, the 'Fins ended the game with RB [[Jesse Chatman]] getting a 7-yard TD run.
With the loss, not only did the Dolphins fall to 0â7 for the first time in franchise history, but they also lost RB [[Ronnie Brown]] for the year, as he tore his ACL in the third quarter while trying to stop an interception return.
====Week 8: vs. New York Giants==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Giants''' |R1=3 |R2=10 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=13 |Home=Dolphins |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=3 |H4=7 |HT=10 |stadium= [[Wembley Stadium]], [[London|London, England]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 59Â°F (Overcast with light rain) |TV=[[NFL on Fox|Fox]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Thom Brennaman]] ([[play-by-play]]), [[Daryl Johnston]] ([[color commentator]]), & [[Tony Siragusa]] (sideline reporter) |referee= [[Gerald Austin|Gerry Austin]] |attendance= 81,176 }} Still trying to get their first win, the Dolphins flew to [[Wembley Stadium]] for their special international interconference game against the [[New York Giants]]. For the game, Miami was listed as the home team. In the first quarter, the Dolphins trailed early as Giants kicker [[Lawrence Tynes]] nailed a 20-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, Miami's struggles continued with N.Y. QB [[Eli Manning]] getting a 10-yard TD run, along with Tynes nailing a 41-yard field goal.
In the third quarter, the 'Fins started to make a comeback as former Giants kicker [[Jay Feely]] got a 29-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, Miami drew close as QB [[Cleo Lemon]] completing a 21-yard TD pass to rookie WR [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] However, New York managed to hold on to their lead for the win.
With their 11th-straight loss, the Dolphins entered their bye week at 0â8.
====Week 10: vs. Buffalo Bills==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bills''' |R1=0||R2=0||R3=2||R4=11||RT=13 |Home=Dolphins |H1=3||H2=0||H3=7||H4=0||HT=10 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EDT]] |weather= 80Â°F (Partly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,615 |referee= [[Bill Carollo]] }} Coming off their bye week and still looking for their first win, the Dolphins went home for an AFC East duel with the [[Buffalo Bills]]. In the first quarter, Miami struck first as kicker [[Jay Feely]] managed to get a 38-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the third quarter, the Bills got on the board with DE [[Chris Kelsey]] sacking QB [[Cleo Lemon]] in the endzone for a safety. Fortunately, the 'Fins responded with Lemon getting a 5-yard TD run. Unfortunately, in the fourth quarter, Miami's year-long struggles continued as Buffalo RB [[Marshawn Lynch]] got a 3-yard TD run, along with a 2-point conversion run. Later, the Bills sealed the win as kicker [[Rian Lindell]] nailed the game-winning 34-yard field goal.
With their ninth-straight loss, the Dolphins fell to 0â9, despite outgaining Buffalo in total offensive yards (269 to 214) and time of possession (36:59 to 23:01).
This marked the 5th time this year that Miami lost by 3 points.
====Week 11: at Philadelphia Eagles==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0 |R2=7 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=7 |Home='''Eagles''' |H1=0 |H2=3 |H3=7 |H4=7 |HT=17 |stadium= [[Lincoln Financial Field]], [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[Eastern Time Zone (North America)|EST]] |weather= 42Â°F (Cloudy) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] ([[play-by-play]]) and [[Rich Gannon]] ([[color commentator]]) |referee= [[Jerome Boger]] |attendance= 68,934 }} Still searching for their first win, the Dolphins flew to [[Lincoln Financial Field]] for a Week 11 interconference duel with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]]. This game would mark the NFL debut of rookie QB [[John Beck (American football)|John Beck]].
After a scoreless first quarter, Miami got the first splash as rookie WR/KR/PR [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] returned a punt 87 yards for a touchdown (the first TD punt return for the Dolphins since 2000). The Eagles would end the half with kicker [[David Akers]] nailing a 34-yard field goal. In the third quarter, Miami's year-long struggles continued as Philadelphia took the lead with RB [[Correll Buckhalter]] getting an 8-yard TD run for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, the Eagles sealed the win with QB [[A. J. Feeley|A.J. Feeley]] (a former Dolphin) completing a 4-yard TD pass to WR [[Jason Avant]].
With the loss, the Dolphins fell to 0â10, eliminating them from playoff contention.<ref>{{cite news | url = http://www.latimes.com/sports/printedition/la-sp-nfl20nov20,1,2544674.story?coll=la-headlines-pe-sports | accessdate = 28 November 2007 }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref> This would be the first time since the 2001 Detroit Lions (who began their year at 0â12) that a team began a season 0â10.
====Week 12: at Pittsburgh Steelers==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0 |R2=0 |R3=0 |R4=0 |RT=0 |Home='''Steelers''' |H1=0 |H2=0 |H3=0 |H4=3 |HT=3 |stadium= [[Heinz Field]], [[Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania]] |time= 8:55 PM EST ([[Monday Night Football]]; game was delayed due to lightning) |weather= Rain/thunderstorms |attendance= 57,704 |referee= [[Jeff Triplette]] |TV=[[ESPN]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Mike Tirico]] (play by play), [[Ron Jaworski]] and [[Tony Kornheiser]] (color commentators), [[Suzy Kolber]] and [[Michele Tafoya]] (sideline reporters) }} Still trying to get their first win of the year, the Dolphins flew to [[Heinz Field]] for a Week 12 Monday Night intraconference duel with the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. For LB [[Joey Porter]], it would be his first game in Pittsburgh against his former team. This would also mark the NFL return of RB [[Ricky Williams]].
Playing in heavy rain with a delay due to lightning, the game (also known as the '''Heinz Field Fiasco''') remained scoreless through over 59 minutes, becoming the longest scoreless tie since 1943. The game would end with Miami falling yet again as Steelers kicker [[Jeff Reed (American football)|Jeff Reed]] got the only points of the game on a fourth-quarter 24-yard field goal with 0:17 left.
With the loss, not only did the Dolphins fall to 0â11, but this would also mark the sixth time this season that the Dolphins lost by 3 points or less (a franchise worst).
In his first NFL game since New Year's Day of 2006, reinstated running back [[Ricky Williams]] had only six carries for 15 yards. He left the game in the second quarter with a torn [[pectoralis major muscle|pectoral]] muscle after fumbling and being stepped on by [[Lawrence Timmons]]. Williams would later be placed on the injured reserve list, ending his season.
====Week 13: vs. New York Jets==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Jets''' |R1=7 |R2=13 |R3=3 |R4=17 |RT=40 |Home=Dolphins |H1=3 |H2=10 |H3=0 |H4=0 |HT=13 |time= 1:00 PM [[North American Eastern Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 81Â°F (Sunny) |referee= [[Mike Carey (American football official)|Mike Carey]] |attendance= 71,109 |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] (play-by-play) and [[Steve Tasker]] (color commentator) }} Still trying to get their first win of the year, the Dolphins went home for a Week 13 AFC East rematch with the throwback-clad [[New York Jets]]. In the first quarter, Miami trailed early as Jets RB [[Leon Washington]] got an 18-yard TD run. The Dolphins would end the period with kicker [[Jay Feely]] getting a 53-yard field goal. In the second quarter, Miami drew closer as Feely kicked a 44-yard field goal, yet New York replied with kicker [[Mike Nugent]] getting a 29-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Dolphins took the lead as CB [[Michael Lehan]] returned a fumble 43 yards for a touchdown. However, the Jets regained the lead with QB [[Kellen Clemens]] completing a 19-yard TD pass to WR [[Brad Smith (American football)|Brad Smith]], along with Nugent kicking a 40-yarder and a 35-yard field goal.
In the third quarter, New York increased their lead with Nugent kicking a 35-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, the Jets sealed the win with RB [[Thomas Jones (American football)|Thomas Jones]] getting a 1-yard TD run, Nugent nailing a 26-yard field goal, and Washington getting a 12-yard TD run.
With the loss, Miami fell to 0â12, and have lost 15 straight games dating back to game 14 of last season. This also marked the first time since the 2001 Detroit Lions that a team began a season 0â12.
====Week 14: at Buffalo Bills==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=7||R2=0||R3=10||R4=0||RT=17 |Home='''Bills''' |H1=24||H2=7||H3=0||H4=7||HT=38 |stadium= [[Ralph Wilson Stadium]], [[Orchard Park, New York]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[North American Eastern Standard Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 30FÂ° (Overcast) |attendance= 71,018 |referee= [[Scott Green (American football official)|Scott Green]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers=[[Ian Eagle]] (play-by-play) & [[Solomon Wilcots]] (color commentator) }} Still trying to get their first win, the Dolphins flew to [[Ralph Wilson Stadium]] for a Week 14 AFC East rematch with the [[Buffalo Bills]]. In the first quarter, Miami's year-long struggles continued as Bills QB [[Trent Edwards]] completed a 13-yard and a 28-yard TD pass to TE [[Robert Royal]], while rookie QB [[John Beck (American football)|John Beck]] had the ball slip out of his hand and have it caught by Buffalo Safety [[George Wilson (safety)|George Wilson]], who would return it 20 yards for a touchdown. The Dolphins would get on the board with RB [[Samkon Gado]] getting a 12-yard TD run, yet the Bills answered with kicker [[Rian Lindell]] getting a 51-yard field goal. In the second quarter, Buffalo continued its dominance as Edwards completed a 9-yard TD pass to WR [[Lee Evans (American football)|Lee Evans]] for the only score of the period.
In the third quarter, the 'Fins tried to rally as Gado got a 20-yard TD run, while kicker [[Jay Feely]] got a 41-yard field goal. However, in the fourth quarter, the Bills sealed the win with Edwards and Evans hooking up with each other again on a 70-yard TD pass.
With yet another loss, the Dolphins fell to 0â13.
This would mark their 16th-straight loss, dating back to last season. Also, Miami became the 5th team in NFL history to begin a season at 0â13.
Despite getting the start, Beck only lasted for the first three series, due to a dismal performance (1/2 for 6 yards).
====Week 15: vs. Baltimore Ravens==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Ravens |R1=3||R2=10||R3=0||R4=3||R5=0||RT=16 |Home='''Dolphins''' |H1=0||H2=3||H3=7||H4=6||H5=6||HT=22 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 p.m. [[North American Eastern Standard Time Zone|EST]] |weather= 79FÂ° (Mostly Cloudy) |attendance= 70,287 |referee= [[John Parry (American football official)|John Parry]] |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Kevin Harlan]] (play-by-play) & [[Rich Gannon]] (color commentator) }} Still in the hunt for their first win of the year, the Dolphins went home for a Week 15 intraconference duel with the [[Baltimore Ravens]]. In the first quarter, Miami trailed early as Ravens kicker [[Matt Stover]] managed to get a 27-yard field goal for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, the Dolphins continued to trail as Stover kicked a 39-yard field goal. Afterwards, the 'Fins got on the board as kicker [[Jay Feely]] managed to get a 23-yard field goal. Baltimore would end the half with QB [[Kyle Boller]] completing a 17-yard TD pass to WR [[Derrick Mason]].
In the third quarter, Miami began to gain steam as RB [[Samkon Gado]] managed to get a 7-yard TD run for the only score of the period. In the fourth quarter, the Dolphins took the lead as Feely kicked a 29-yard and an 18-yard field goal. Afterwards, the Ravens tie the game with Stover nailing an 18-yard field goal. In overtime, the demons were lifted as QB [[Cleo Lemon]] completed the game-winning 64-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Camarillo]]. Soon after players and coaches rejoiced in the locker room after a long awaited first win.
With the win, not only did Miami improve to 1â13, but it also snapped a 16-game losing streak dating back to last season's December 15 win over the [[New England Patriots]], notching their first win of the 2007 season and avoiding their becoming the first team in NFL history to go 0â16. This would turn out to be their only win in a dismal 1â15 and would keep them from being possibly labeled as the worst team in NFL history. They also avoided having to play with a 0â14 record against a New England Patriots team carrying the complimentary 14â0 record, and widely rooted for to become the first team in over 30 years to match the perfect season feat originally posted by the Dolphins.
For Cleo Lemon, he would get his first career 300-yard game, as he completed 23 out of 39 passes for 315 yards and 1 touchdown.
====Week 16: at New England Patriots==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road=Dolphins |R1=0||R2=0||R3=7||R4=0||RT=7 |Home='''Patriots''' |H1=7||H2=21||H3=0||H4=0||HT=28 |stadium= [[Gillette Stadium]], [[Foxboro, Massachusetts]] |time= 4:15 p.m. EST |weather= 43Â°F (Cloudy and mild with rain) |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Jim Nantz]] (play-by-play) and [[Phil Simms]] (color commentator) |referee= [[Ron Winter]] |attendance= 68,756 }} Coming off their home win over the Ravens, the Dolphins flew to [[Gillette Stadium]] for a Week 16 AFC East rematch with the undefeated [[New England Patriots]]. In the first quarter, Miami trailed early as Patriots QB [[Tom Brady]] completed an 11-yard TD pass to WR [[Randy Moss]] for the only score of the period. In the second quarter, New England pulled away with Brady & Moss hooked up with each other again on a 1-yard TD pass, RB [[Laurence Maroney]] getting a 59-yard TD run, and Brady completing a 48-yard TD pass to WR [[Jabar Gaffney]]. In the third quarter, the Dolphins would get on the board as QB [[Cleo Lemon]] completed a 21-yard TD pass to WR [[Greg Camarillo]]. However, the Patriots' defense took over for the rest of the game.
With the loss, Miami fell to 1â14.
====Week 17: vs. Cincinnati Bengals==== {{Americanfootballbox| |Road='''Bengals''' |R1=7||R2=14||R3=7||R4=10||RT=38 |Home=Dolphins |H1=3||H2=7||H3=0||H4=15||HT=25 |stadium= [[Dolphin Stadium]], [[Miami Gardens, Florida]] |time= 1:00 p.m. EST |weather= 81Â°F |TV=[[NFL on CBS|CBS]] |TVAnnouncers= [[Gus Johnson (sportscaster)|Gus Johnson]] (play-by-play) and [[Steve Tasker]] (color commentator) |referee= [[Walt Coleman]] |attendance= 70,461 }} Hoping to finish their horrendous season on a high note, the Dolphins went home for a Week 17 intraconference duel with the [[Cincinnati Bengals]]. In the first quarter, Miami struck first as kicker [[Jay Feeley]] managed to get a 49-yard field goal. The Bengals would take the lead as QB [[Carson Palmer]] completed a 2-yard TD pass to WR [[Chad Ochocinco|Chad Johnson]]. In the second quarter, the 'Fins regained the lead as QB [[Cleo Lemon]] completed a 5-yard TD to rookie WR [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]], yet Cincinnati retook the lead with Palmer completing a 70-yard TD pass to Chad Johnson and a 4-yard TD pass to WR [[Antonio Chatman]].
In the third quarter, the Bengals increased their lead with Safety [[Chinedum Ndukwe]] returning a fumble 54 yards for a touchdown. In the fourth quarter, the Dolphins tried to come back as rookie QB [[John Beck (American football)|John Beck]] got a 2-yard TD run, but Cincinnati pulled away as RB [[Kenny Watson]] got a 2-yard TD run and kicker [[Shayne Graham]] nailing a 30-yard field goal. Miami ended the game with Beck completing a 22-yard TD pass to WR [[Derek Hagan]].
With the loss, the Dolphins ended their season at 1â15.
===Standings=== {{2007 AFC East standings}}
===Transactions=== ====September==== During the Dolphins' Week 1 loss to the Redskins, starting [[Safety (American football position)|strong safety]] [[Yeremiah Bell]] suffered a torn [[Achilles' tendon]]. As a result, he was placed on season-ending [[Injured Reserve]] on September 11. The team also waived backup [[defensive end]] [[Akbar Gbaja-Biamila]], who did not play in the season opener. With two open spots on the 53-man roster, the team signed contracts with veteran safeties and [[Donovin Darius]] and [[Lamont Thompson]]. They were waived by the [[Oakland Raiders]] and [[Tennessee Titans]], respectively, at the end of the preseason. The same day, rookie linebacker [[Kelvin Smith]], who was waived four days earlier, was re-signed to the team's practice squad.
====October==== On the first day of the month, linebacker [[Robert McCune]] was waived from injured reserve. Linebacker Jim Maxwell suffered the same fate eight days later.
The Dolphins' active roster remained unchanged for nearly a month after the season opener. The first transactions since came on October 10, when defensive tackle [[Sam Rayburn (American football)|Sam Rayburn]] was signed and safety [[Lamont Thompson]] was released. Thompson appeared in one game for the Dolphins after being signed on September 11 and made one tackle. Rayburn went to training camp with the [[San Francisco 49ers]] in 2007 after spending the first four years of his career with the [[Philadelphia Eagles]].
On October 16, Miami traded their No. 1 receiver, seven-year veteran [[Chris Chambers]], to the [[San Diego Chargers]] in exchange for a second-round pick in the [[2008 NFL Draft]]. In 100 games with the Dolphins since being drafted in the second round of the [[2001 NFL Draft]], Chambers caught 405 passes for 5,688 yards and 43 touchdowns. He earned his first [[Pro Bowl]] selection in 2005. In the team's first six games of the 2007 season, he caught 31 passes for 415 yards with no touchdowns. On the same day, the team also released safety [[Donovin Darius]] and placed defensive tackle [[Chase Page]] on injured reserve.
To fill the three roster spots vacated by Chambers, Darius and Page, the Dolphins signed three defensive linemen â tackles [[Anthony Bryant (American football)|Anthony Bryant]] and [[Jesse Mahelona]] and end [[Derreck Robinson]]. Bryant was on the practice squad of the [[Baltimore Ravens]] prior to his signing. Mahelona and Robinson had been released by the [[Tennessee Titans]] and [[San Diego Chargers]], respectively, in September.
After suffering a concussion in the team's Week 5 game against the [[Houston Texans]], starting quarterback [[Trent Green]] was placed on injured reserve on October 20. Wide receiver [[Kerry Reed]] â an undrafted free agent from Michigan State â was promoted to the active roster from the practice squad.
Three days later, defensive tackle Jesse Mahelona was waived after being inactive for one game with the team. Starting running back [[Ronnie Brown]] and starting free safety [[Renaldo Hill]] were both placed on injured reserve with torn ACLs suffered in the team's Week 7 game against the [[New England Patriots]]. Brown was leading the NFL in offensive yards at the time of the injury.
On October 24, two of the three roster spots were filled from outside the organization as the Dolphins signed defensive end [[Quentin Moses]] and safety [[Lance Schulters]]. Moses was originally drafted by the [[Oakland Raiders]] in the third round of the [[2007 NFL Draft]] and was claimed off waivers by the [[Arizona Cardinals]] on September 2. He was inactive for six games before being waived. Schulters spent the latter part of the 2006 season with the Atlanta Falcons after starting for the Dolphins in 2005. Tight end [[Aaron Halterman]] was also promoted from the practice squad.
Additionally, running back [[Samkon Gado]] was claimed off waivers from the [[Houston Texans]]. The team was granted a one-game roster exemption, as Gado was unable to meet the Dolphins in time for their October 28 game in [[London]]. On October 30, defensive tackle Sam Rayburn was waived to make room for Gado on the active roster.
The Dolphins also filled two practice squad spots vacated by Reed and Halterman with quarterback [[Casey Bramlet]] and tight end [[Buck Ortega]]. A seventh-round pick by the [[Cincinnati Bengals]] in 2004, Bramlet spent 2007 training camp with the Atlanta Falcons. Ortega had been waived by the [[Cleveland Browns]] in late August.
====November==== On November 6, the Dolphins placed linebacker [[Abraham Wright]] â one of the team's seventh-round picks in 2007 â on injured reserve with a knee injury. He had inactive for all eight of the team's games in 2007. Practice squad tight end [[Buck Ortega]] was released the same day. The following day, defensive back [[Jereme Perry]] was signed to the active roster an undrafted free agent wide receiver [[Stefan Logan]] ([[University of South Dakota|South Dakota]]) was signed to the practice squad. Perry had spent the 2006 season and 2007 training camp with the [[Cleveland Browns]].
On November 14, safety [[Travares Tillman]] was placed on injured reserve with a knee injury. [[Tuff Harris]] â an undrafted defensive back from [[Montana Grizzlies|Montana]] â was promoted from the practice squad to the active roster. Placekicker [[Matt Prater]], who spent training camp with the Dolphins, was re-signed to the practice squad. Prater briefly held the kicking job for the Atlanta Falcons, but was waived on September 19 after going 1-for-4 on field goal in two games.
On November 19, running back [[Ricky Williams]] was reinstated by the NFL. Williams had been suspended since the 2006 offseason for his fourth violation of the league substance abuse policy. The team was granted a one-week roster exemption for Williams.
Williams' return to the Dolphins did not last long, however. After being activated by the Dolphins when running back [[Samkon Gado]] was waived on November 26, Williams suffered a torn pectoral muscle against the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]]. He was placed on injured reserve on November 28 and Gado was re-signed.
Despite returning to practice on November 6, offensive lineman [[Joe Toledo]] â on the physically-unable-to-perform list since training camp â was unable to return to the active roster for the 2007 season. His practice period expired on November 27, forcing him to remain on the PUP list for the remainder of the season.
====December==== On December 4, starting middle linebacker [[Zach Thomas]] was placed on injured reserve with lingering effects of a concussion suffered earlier in the season. Safety [[Cameron Worrell]] became the third starting strong safety to be placed on injured reserve after suffering a torn ACL in the team's Week 13 game against the [[New York Jets]]. Wide receiver [[Kerry Reed]] was also waived by the team after spending six games on the active roster.
To fill two of the roster spots, linebacker [[Kelvin Smith]] and offensive tackle [[Julius Wilson]] were promoted to the active roster from the practice squad. Both rookies, Smith had originally been drafted in the seventh round out of [[Syracuse Orange#Football|Syracuse]] in 2007 while Wilson was signed as an undrafted free agent out of [[UAB Blazers|UAB]]. Filling the third spot was rookie linebacker [[Mark Washington (linebacker)|Mark Washington]], who was signed off the practice squad of the [[San Francisco 49ers]].
Wide receiver Kerry Reed was re-signed to the practice squad after being waived by the team, and linebacker [[Marcello Church]] was signed to the practice squad as well. Church went undrafted out of [[Florida State Seminoles football|Florida State]] in 2006 and had spent part of the 2007 offseason with the [[Pittsburgh Steelers]].
===Awards and honors=== Dolphins players received two weekly honors during the 2007 season. Wide receiver [[Ted Ginn, Jr.]] won [[Diet Pepsi NFL Rookie of the Week]] honors for his performance against the [[Philadelphia Eagles]] in Week 11, during which he returned a punt 87 yard for a touchdown (the first of his career) and also caught four passes for 52 yards.<ref>[http://www.nfl.com/partner?partnerType=rookies&season=2007&seasonType=REG&week=11 NFL.com â Rookie of the Week<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
In Week 15, quarterback [[Cleo Lemon]] won [[American Football Conference|AFC]] Offensive Player of the Week honors for leading the Dolphins to their first victory of the season against the [[Baltimore Ravens]].<ref name="LemonAward">[http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5591 Cleo Lemon Named AFC Offensive Player Of The Week; Camarillo Still Popular; Injury Update â NEWS: Top Story Presented by WACHOVIA â MiamiDolphins.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In the game, Lemon went 23-for-39 for 315 yards and threw a game-winning 64-yard touchdown pass to [[Greg Camarillo]] in overtime.<ref name="LemonAward"/>
On December 18, it was announced that defensive end [[Jason Taylor (American football)|Jason Taylor]] was selected to the [[2008 Pro Bowl]] â his fourth straight selection and sixth overall.<ref>[http://www.miamidolphins.com/newsite/news/top_story.asp?contentID=5589&lid=5589 Jason Taylor Named To AFC Pro Bowl Squad â NEWS: Top Story Presented by WACHOVIA â MiamiDolphins.com<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> Taylor finished the 2007 season with 56 tackles (47 solo), 11 sacks, four passes defensed and an interception returned for a touchdown.<ref>[http://www.nfl.com/players/jasontaylor/profile?id=TAY338550 Jason Taylor<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
